sections.section: This tutorial demonstrates how a RESTRequest node can be used to call REST APIs. A simple application has been created, containing a message flow which receives XML data over HTTP (using an HTTPInput node). The XML data is parsed and passed to a RESTRequest node. The RESTRequest node's properties specify where the REST API is running (in this tutorial this will be your localhost), and the Request parameter to send. The REST API implements a GET operation, in which a graphical data mapping node is used to 'retrieve' information (actually the values are hard coded in a map) about a user based on the input data.

In IBM Integration Bus, an application is a container for all the resources that are required to create a solution. An application can contain IBM Integration Bus resources, such as flows, message definitions, libraries, and JAR files. In this tutorial, an application is used to hold the message flow which contains the RESTRequest node. A referenced shared Library is used, to hold an XML schema to describe the input data and a Swagger file to describe the interface of the REST API which is invoked.

sections.section: Before deploying the provided REST API in your Integration Server, enable Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS).

details.details:
In your Integration Console run the following command:
mqsichangeproperties TESTNODE_userid -e default -o HTTPConnector -n corsEnabled -v true
where
TESTNODE_userid is the name of your Integration Node
and
default is the name of your Integration Server.

In the Integration console window, stop the default integration node by typing the following command:
mqsistop TESTNODE_userid

Start the default integration node by typing the following command:
mqsistart TESTNODE_userid

sections.section: The imported artifacts are all ready for you to test:

details.details: Deploy RESTRequest_API by dragging and dropping it on to your integration server
Inside the RESTRequest_Client application, open the RESTRequest_Client message flow, and click the Flow Exerciser icon to start recording the message path through the flow.
Click the Send Message icon to select a message to send to the flow.
Choose the 'User 1' message, and click Send. Your request message is sent to the HTTPInput node.
The dialog will show you the input XML message structure: <User><UserNumber>1</UserNumber></User>
The dialog will show you the output JSON message structure: {"userNumber":"1","firstName":"Peter","lastName":"Pan","userDetails":"Employee"}

sections.section: Close the dialog and the message path is automatically highlighted on the message flow. Click on any connection to see the data that passed through that connection.
Feel free to test the REST API by sending 'User 2' or 'User 3' test messages, following the above instructions.
